title: Hogs survive fantastic four
text:
Hogs survive fantastic four Nate Allen, nallensports@att.net 5:09 p.m. CDT October 25, 2015 Arkansas tight end Hunter Henry (84) drags along Auburn linebacker Jeff Holland (4) after a reception during the game between the Razorbacks and the Tigers at Reynolds Razorback Stadium in Fayetteville. Arkansas won 54-46 in four overtimes. (Photo: Alan Jamison/Nate Allen Sports Service) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
FAYETTEVILLE — At least for a couple of days, the Internet message boards and radio sports talk shows finally should abound extolling Brandon Allen for winning a big SEC close game instead of entirely blaming him because Arkansas lost one. 
Actually, Arkansas’ fifth-year senior quarterback made enough plays to win five big close games Saturday, given the Razorbacks never trailed in regulation, then needed Allen’s big plays through four overtimes to outlast the Auburn Tigers, 54-46, in the SEC West game before an announced 72,008 at Reynolds Razorback Stadium. 
The emotion-filled SEC triumph for Bret Bielema’s Razorbacks over former Arkansas high school championship coach and former Arkansas offensive coordinator Gus Malzahn’s Tigers boosts Arkansas to 3-4, 2-2 in the SEC West going into next Saturday’s 3 p.m. nonconference game with Tennessee-Martin at Reynolds Razorback Stadium. 
Auburn falls to 4-3, 1-3 in the SEC West, and hosts SEC West rival Ole Miss next Saturday. 
Passing 19 of 31 for 233 yards and three touchdowns against one interception, running 20 yards that included two key designed runs for first downs on third down, and even receiving an 11-yard overtime, throwback pass from wide receiver/former quarterback Duwop Mitchell, Allen did it all in the 11 a.m. game that lasted past 4 p.m. 
By doing it all with a lot of help from his offensive friends, Allen snapped three seasons of never winning close SEC games including three previous overtime games to Mississippi State in 2013 and to Texas A&M in 2014 and this season’s SEC opener. 
Allen’s finishing touches Saturday were a fourth overtime 25-yard touchdown pass to Drew Morgan and 2-point conversion passes to to returned from the injured running back Kody Walker then watching Arkansas safety Josh Liddell break up Auburn quarterback Sean White’s fourth and nine pass for Ricardo Louis, the Auburn receiver whose three big catches during the final 1:07 of regulation set up the Auburn field goal for the 24-24 regulation tie but who dropped a would-be fourth-overtime touchdown two plays before Liddell’s breakup saved Arkansas’ longest day of 2014. 
“Well, I’m glad that game was at 11 or else we would be here until midnight,” Bielema said. 
The coach would have stayed through Sunday morning to see his Hogs and his quarterback so elated. 
“A lot more fun, I’ll tell you that,” Allen said when asked to contrast Saturday’s success with all the close but no cigars. “Yeah, we knew we could always make plays. I’ve always had confidence in myself and the guys to do it. Tonight we kind of just put it together when we needed to late in the game. It was a great win for the team.” 
Obviously it wasn’t so great for Malzahn. 
He saw his team rebound from 14-0 tie it 14-14 then respond to tie it 21-21 and 24-24 before the twists and turns in overtime. 
“First of all that was a tough one,” Malzahn said. “No doubt about it. Our guys played with a lot of heart You have to give Arkansas credit. They responded numerous times when they had to. They made plays and we just didn’t get it done.” 
Asked about Louis’ drop during the fourth overtime, Malzahn said, “Ricardo made two plays to send it to overtime. That (the OT drop) is a tough deal.” 
Arkansas’ overtime also highlighted Walker, summoned especially in the second half with lead running back Alex Collins 25 carries for 105 yards a 7-yard touchdown, banged up and backup freshman Rawleigh Williams (hospitalized with a third-quarter neck injury but conscious and moving his extremities, Bielema said. Walker rushed for 3 and 4-yard overtime touchdowns. 
Also in Arkansas’ overtime, Allen threw an overtime 2-point pass to tight end Jeremy Sprinkle and Cole Hedlund, a 25-yard field goal for the 24-21 lead with 1:07 left in regulation, kicked two overtime PAT’s before 2-point tries became mandated from the third overtime on. 
For Auburn’s overtime running back Peyton Barber rushed for three touchdowns. Daniel Carlson, whose 41-yard field goal with four seconds left in regulation wrought overtime, kicked two overtime PAT’s before White’s 2-point pass to Melvin Ray achieved the 38-38 tie completing the third overtime. 
Arkansas started fast, leading 14-0 by its third possession. 
Junior college transfer and Camden Fairview grad receiver Dominique Reed tally the game’s first touchdown on an 11-yard jet sweep at 11:33 of the first quarter, completing a 75-yard drive that included three Allen passes to tight end Hunter Henry for 52 yards. 
Henry wouldn’t catch another until the overtime. 
Arkansas started its second scoring drive at 3:59 in the second quarter and finished it with Allen’s 23-yard touchdown pass to Sprinkle at 14:22 of the second quarter. 
The Hogs appeared ripe to make it 21-0 until Allen threw his only pick, intercepted by Kris Frost at the Auburn four. Read or Share this story: http://www.baxterbulletin.com/story/sports/2015/10/25/hogs-survive-fantastic-four/74599102/ TOP VIDEOS
